title: Traumatic Diaphragmatic Rupture
diagnosis_topic: Left diaphragmatic tear from blunt trauma with herniation
setup_script: A 45-year-old man presents after a high-speed motor vehicle collision with airbag deployment. He complains of left chest and abdominal pain.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 125/80 mmHg, HR 100 bpm, RR 24/min, SpO2 93% on room air.
Decreased breath sounds on the left, bowel sounds audible in chest, abdomen tender with guarding.
Shows elevated left hemidiaphragm and opacification; nasogastric tube seen curling into chest.
It coils within thoracic cavity confirming diagnosis and decompresses stomach.
Herniation of stomach and splenic flexure into left hemithorax through diaphragmatic defect.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults thoracic surgery for operative repair
dynamic_flow.reply: Proceed to OR for laparoscopic or open reduction and diaphragmatic repair.
Patient develops respiratory distress and strangulation of herniated organs.
High-energy blunt trauma, seatbelt injuries, or penetrating trauma; often missed initially.
Evaluate for splenic laceration, rib fractures and pelvic fractures.
Monitor for recurrence, manage chest tube if placed, encourage pulmonary toileting.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident assesses for right diaphragmatic injury
dynamic_flow.reply: Rare due to liver protection; CT and MRI helpful.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident counsels regarding seat belt use

critical_decision_points: Suspicion for diaphragmatic rupture in high-energy trauma
Diagnostic use of chest X-ray, nasogastric tube and CT imaging
Timely surgical repair to prevent herniation and strangulation
